results.title: Best Movies of 2022
results.abstract: Amid endless agonizing over the State of Cinema, the actual releases proved a bounty for film lovers, whether fans of the art house or the multiplex.
results.byline: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott

results.title: What Makes a Movie the Greatest of All Time?
results.abstract: The much-respected Sight and Sound poll of the best films ever shows that what is valued onscreen has changed over time, sometimes radically.
results.byline: By Eric Grode, Weiyi Cai, Rumsey Taylor and Josh Williams

results.title: A Very Streaming Christmas
results.abstract: With so many Christmas movies to stream this season, which ones are quality nuggets and which are lumps of coal?

results.title: We’re Out of Movie Stars. Whose Fault Is That?
results.abstract: There are fewer films now that allow an actor to grow a persona and a Tom Cruise level of stardom. It’s a crisis, and the movies know it.

results.title: When Santa Slays: Holiday Genre Movies
results.abstract: With the release of “Violent Night,” here’s a guide to streaming genre films that feature a not-always-jolly St. Nick.

results.title: Discussing the ‘Fat Suit’ at ‘The Whale’ Premiere
results.abstract: More than 100 actors, singers and creative professionals attended the New York premiere of Darren Aronofsky’s new film at Alice Tully Hall this week. Some of them shared their thoughts.

results.title: A Trans Icon of the 20th Century Revived by Trans Stars of the 21st Century
results.abstract: The documentary “Framing Agnes” uses transcripts to tell the story of an anonymous woman who became the subject of a series of landmark interviews.

multimedia.caption: Casey Minatrea, left, Chase Joynt, Carmen Dianne and Zackary Drucker work on a stylized talk show that “Framing Agnes” stages to examine questions that academics and TV hosts asked about transness.

results.title: 10 Stages and Screens Where I Saw Connection
results.abstract: For our critic-at-large, “Fat Ham,” “Severance,” “A Strange Loop” and “Sandman” were some of the places she found truth and transcendence.

results.title: 11 Ways I Escaped Reality This Year

results.title: For Emma Corrin, Identity Is an Ever-Evolving Project
results.abstract: Onscreen and off, the nonbinary star of “Lady Chatterley’s Lover” and “The Crown” has been exploring gender and the cost and responsibility of being heard.

multimedia.caption: “My identity and being nonbinary is an embrace of many different parts of myself, the masculine and the feminine and everything in between,” Emma Corrin said.

results.title: Julia Reichert, Documentarian of the Working Class, Dies at 76
results.abstract: She took home, to Ohio, a 2019 Oscar for “American Factory,” and in a long career teaching and making films, she paid special attention to working women.

multimedia.caption: Julia Reichert with her husband and co-director Steven Bognar in Los Angeles after their film “An American Factory” won the 2019 Academy Award for best documentary feature.

results.title: A Versatile Director Brings Powerful Imagery to Wagner and Film
results.abstract: Kornel Mundruczo’s varied career has included the Oscar-nominated movie “Pieces of a Woman,” stage productions across Europe and now, “Lohengrin.”

results.title: Yes, ‘Cocaine Bear’ Was Real. Here’s the Back Story.
results.abstract: Nearly 40 years after a 175-pound black bear found and ingested cocaine in a Georgia forest, the drug binge has inspired a movie.

multimedia.caption: The movie “Cocaine Bear” offers a fictionalized account of what happened when a black bear found several pounds of cocaine in Georgia in 1985.
